comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Since this photo is next to a photo of Speaker Joseph Gurney Cannon, I thought it worth checking whether this could be his daughter. According to www.usgenealogyexpress.com/~il/vermilion/vermco_bios_c.ht... his daughters were Helen and Mabel. At the time this text was written (in the History of Vermilion County, Volume II, published in 1911 [http://lccn.loc.gov/11020501]) , Helen was unmarried and Mabel was Mrs. Ernest X. LeSeure. Mabel had two children Virginia and Helen. Mabel's dates are Birth: May 23, 1867 Death: Mar. 29, 1930 www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=11794525 The girl above is clearly younger than 47 -- so Mildred is not a mistake for Mabel. But it seems worth recording this negative evidence.

The newspapers say she is the niece of Joseph Gurney Cannon.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Chicago Day Book March 25, 1914 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1914-03-2... agrees on the character of the young lady, but suggests she is Joseph Gurney Cannon's grand-niece. At top of left-hand column: '"Go to it," Uncle Joe Cannon is said to have advised grand niece, Mildred Ann Cannon, when sheannounced desire to become professional tangoer. Reported receiving $500 a week. Her father objected.'
